newsitem.title: USA: NBA BASKETBALL-BULLETS KNOCK MIAMI OUT OF FIRST PLACE.
newsitem.headline: NBA BASKETBALL-BULLETS KNOCK MIAMI OUT OF FIRST PLACE.

text.p: Tracy Murray scored 16 of his season-high 22 points in the fourth quarter Thursday as the Washington Bullets knocked the Miami Heat out of first place in the Atlantic Division, 99-95.

Murray made four three-pointers in the final period. He hit a three-pointer with 2:54 to play to draw Washington within 88-87. He drained another three-pointer on the Bullets' next possesion and Washington never gave up the lead.

Rod Strickland, who hit three crucial free throws in the final seconds to seal the victory, had 19 points for Washington, which has won three straight but is 4 1/2 games out of the last playoff spot in the Eastern Conference.
The Heat had a chance to tie the game with three seconds to go but Voshon Lenard's three-pointer rimmed out and Strickland came down with the rebound.
"Our backs are against the wall," Murray said. "There is a sense of urgency. The way we played tonight in the second half, if we can keep it up we can win most of our games."
Isaac Austin scored a career-high 19 points and Jamal Mashburn also had 19 for Miami, which fell a half game behind the New York Knicks atop the Atlantic Division.
The Heat, out of first for the first time since January 15, have played their last six games without All-Star centre Alonzo Mourning, who is out with a foot injury.
"We had a lead we should have kept," Heat coach Pat Riley said. "They kept their offence alive by hitting the boards, keeping the ball alive and kicking the ball out."
Without Mourning, the Heat was beaten on the boards 52-41 and shot just 40 percent (33-of-82) from the floor. Miami also got just 14 points from its bench.
"It was a terrible loss, that sums it up," Miami forward P.J. Brown said. "It's probably the worst loss of the year."
In Charlotte, Glen Rice set a franchise record with 48 points and Vlade Divac added four of his 23 and a key defensive play in overtime as the Hornets defeated the Boston Celtics 122-121.
Anthony Mason had his second straight triple-double and fourth of the season with 19 points, 14 rebounds and 12 assists for Charlotte. The Hornets have won four straight and nine of their last 10.
Divac just missed a triple-double with 18 rebounds and nine assists.

"Anthony Mason was really good, got a triple-double," Charlotte coach Dave Cowens said. "All these records were falling. We almost had two guys that had triple-doubles in the same night, which would have been pretty outstanding."
Eric Williams scored 25 points and Antoine Walker 20 for the Celtics, who blew an eight-point lead in the final four minutes of the fourth quarter and fell to 3-29 on the road.
On their last possession, the Celtics threw the ball in to Williams, but Divac tipped it to Dell Curry and the Hornets ran out the clock.

"I was passing the ball," Williams said. "He just made a great play. He has been in the league a long time and is playing well for Charlotte. He has long arms and he just reached around and knocked the ball away. He had to make a great play, otherwise we had a layup."
In Los Angeles, Penny Hardaway scored 21 points and Dennis Scott added 19 as the Orlando Magic edged the Clippers 94-93 for their eighth win in nine games.
Loy Vaught had 28 points and 12 rebounds and Darrick Martin finished with 16 points for the Clippers, who went down to their third straight loss.
In Philadelphia, the Atlanta Hawks led from start to finish, cruising to a 117-104 victory over the 76ers.
Steve Smith had 25 points and a season-high 10 assists and Christian Laettner added 23 points for Atlanta, which has won eight of its last 11 games.
Derrick Coleman scored 23 points and Allen Iverson 20 for Philadelphia, which has lost three straight and fell to 8-22 at home.

In Vancouver, Sam Cassell had 26 points and 10 assists before leaving with a leg cramp in the final minute as the New Jersey Nets scored a 102-96 victory over the Grizzlies, snapping a six-game road losing streak.
Kendall Gill scored 22 points and rookie Kerry Kittles 21 for the Nets, who won for just the third time in their last nine games but improved to 3-0 all-time against Vancouver.
Anthony Peeler scored 24 points and Shareef Abdur-Rahim 23 for the Grizzlies, who suffered their eighth straight loss.
